g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute

area basis, carbon stocks in coastal ecosystems can be
ground carbon storage up to 1000 tC
(Crooks et al. 2018; McLeod et al. 2011; Bindoff et al. 2019)
have a mitigation potential of around 0.5% of current global emissions, with an upper limit of less than
Restoration or protection of coastal ecosystems is an important adaptation action with multip
restoration/preservation reduces coastal erosion and protects from storm surges, and otherwise mitigates
impacts of sea level rise and extreme wea
. Restoration of tidal flow to coastal wetlands inhibits methane emissions which
occur in fresh and brackish water
ecosystem services provided by coastal wetlands).
significant social benefits in the form of job creation (through tourism and recreation opportunities), as
well as ecological benefits through habitat preservation
Grier and Moore 2016; Kairo et al. 2018; Wylie et al. 2016; Bindoff et al. 2019)
One concern is to assure that actions remain effective at higher levels of climate change
Also, methane emissions from ecosystems may partially reduce the benefit
As the main driver of mangrove
, there may be entrenched interests opposing restoration and protection actions.
Restoration and protection of terrestrial ecosystems
Restoration of terrestrial landscapes can be a direct outcome of development pathways, and can be
critical to achieving a variety of
although it also presents risks and can
. Landscape restoration is nearly always a mitigation action, and can also provide
adaptive capacity. While policy in Brazil has tended to focus on the Amazon as a carbon sink, the
based adaptation actions have been highlighted in the literature
Gregorio et al. 2016; Locatelli et al. 2011)
. A study of potential restoration of degraded lands in Latin
indicates that substantial benefits for mitigation, adaptation, and
economic development accrue after several years, underscoring a reliance on deliberate development
In agricultural contexts, restoration is a development choice that can enhance
mitigative capacity via impact on farmer livelihoods.
Preventing degradation of landscapes can support both mitigation and adaptation
Restoration of ecosystems is associated with improved water filtration, ground water recharge and flood
control and multiple other ecosystem services
Restoration projects must be designed with care.
Restorations may be unsuccessful if not considered in their socio
(Lengefeld et al. 2020; Iftekhar et al. 2017; Jellinek et al. 2019)
tion purposes can be more effective if done with adaptation in mind
Landscape restoration projects intended for CDR may underperform due to future release of stored
, or deferral of storage until after irreversible climate change effects (e.g. extinctions)
